channel.title: The indestructible
channel.description:
The stories of Ukrainians who had seen the war and the occupiers face to face, but who survived and managed to move on. Each of the heroes has experienced shocking situations and painful losses, but despite this, they maintain an active life position. The program also involves foreign psychologists who have worked with participants and witnesses of other wars. The experience of the project's heroes and the psychologists' comments will help you understand oneself and find motivation for one’s future.
Ukrainian version — listen here.
This programme was produced with the financial support of the European Union. Its contents are the sole responsibility of National Public Broadcasting Company of Ukraine and do not necessarily reflect the views of the European Union.

item.title: Hanna Biliayeva from the Luhansk region. She is married to Oleksandr Biliayev, a fighter with the call sign “Freeman”. To this day he is Russian captivity. Hanna believes that one day he shall make it back home.
item.description: Hanna Biliayeva from the Luhansk region. She is married to Oleksandr Biliayev, a fighter with the call sign “Freeman”. To this day he is Russian captivity. Hanna believes that one day he shall make it back home.

item.title: The story of Natalia Fokina’s fight. During civil time she was a costume designer at the Mykola Kulish Kherson region theatre of music and drama. In war time she became a partisan, helping to rid her home city from the occupiers.
item.description: The story of Natalia Fokina’s fight. During civil time she was a costume designer at the Mykola Kulish Kherson region theatre of music and drama. In war time she became a partisan, helping to rid her home city from the occupiers.

item.title: Marina Kuraptseva - journalist, activist, media-coach and twice displaced person, who has had to start all anew each time.
item.description: Marina Kuraptseva - journalist, activist, media-coach and twice displaced person, who has had to start all anew each time.

item.title: Life after loss. Serhiy and Lyudmila lived a long life together and would do everything together. They had no common children. They had almost finished building their own cafe, but could not open the business… Now Lyudmila cannot even return to the place where they spent so many of their years together.
item.description: Life after loss. Serhiy and Lyudmila lived a long life together and would do everything together. They had no common children. They had almost finished building their own cafe, but could not open the business… Now Lyudmila cannot even return to the place where they spent so many of their years together.

item.title: A story of the despair and hope of Viktoria Zhuravlyova, a resident of a destroyed building block in Irpin.
item.description: A story of the despair and hope of Viktoria Zhuravlyova, a resident of a destroyed building block in Irpin.

item.title: While some are hiding from the war, others are liberating occupied territories - fighting for victory through pain and loss. The story of Serhiy Nikoliutin.
item.description: While some are hiding from the war, others are liberating occupied territories - fighting for victory through pain and loss. The story of Serhiy Nikoliutin.

item.title: The story of Ivan Havrylko, a former geologist, whose life was changed by the war. First the war in Donbas, then the full-scale invasion, and three traumas that drove him to learn to live anew.
item.description: The story of Ivan Havrylko, a former geologist, whose life was changed by the war. First the war in Donbas, then the full-scale invasion, and three traumas that drove him to learn to live anew.

item.title: The experience of journalists during the war on the example of Olena Maksymenko’s and Maria Lebedieva’s stories.
item.description: The experience of journalists during the war on the example of Olena Maksymenko’s and Maria Lebedieva’s stories.

item.title: Vladyslav Kopychko was one of the many who was waiting for train at the Kramatorsk train station on April 8, and one of those who managed to survive despite numerous injuries. A story of struggle, perseverance, and gratitude.
item.description: Vladyslav Kopychko was one of the many who was waiting for train at the Kramatorsk train station on April 8, and one of those who managed to survive despite numerous injuries. A story of struggle, perseverance, and gratitude.

item.title: Iryna Tsybukh, a volunteer with the Hospitallers battalion, is a paramedic and medical crew leader. Together with her team, she ensures evacuation from the battlefield and provides medical assistance.
item.description: Iryna Tsybukh, a volunteer with the Hospitallers battalion, is a paramedic and medical crew leader. Together with her team, she ensures evacuation from the battlefield and provides medical assistance.

item.title: Before the war started, Yulia Bartle was a businesswoman, but she has been volunteering for 9 years. She considers herself to be one of those Ukrainians who knew that a large-scale invasion would happen, but could not imagine that the Russians would come so close to the capital, and so quickly.
item.description: Before the war started, Yulia Bartle was a businesswoman, but she has been volunteering for 9 years. She considers herself to be one of those Ukrainians who knew that a large-scale invasion would happen, but could not imagine that the Russians would come so close to the capital, and so quickly.
